description:
Lasiosphaeria miniovina is a type of ascomycete fungus that belongs to the family Lasiosphaeriaceae. It is a saprobic fungus, meaning it feeds on decaying organic matter, and is commonly found growing on dead wood, plant debris, and dung.

The species is characterized by its small, spherical ascomata (fruiting bodies) that are densely covered with dark brown to black hairs. The asci (spore-bearing structures) are cylindrical, containing eight ascospores. The ascospores are typically ellipsoid or fusiform in shape, with or without septation (internal divisions).

Lasiosphaeria miniovina is considered a microfungus, as its fruiting bodies are typically less than 1 millimeter in diameter. It plays an important role in the decomposition of organic matter, contributing to nutrient cycling in various ecosystems.

The identification and classification of Lasiosphaeria miniovina are based on its morphological characteristics, as well as molecular analyses of its genetic information. It is part of a diverse group of fungi that contribute to the overall biodiversity and functioning of terrestrial ecosystems.
